_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Ammonia Vaporizers, Ammonia Injection Skid, Tank Skid
_prev_prog_3.Description: Wygen 1 unit uses ammonia in its Selective Catalyst Reactor (SCR) as a process control.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Black Hills Corporation, Wygen 1 Power Plant maintains one substance, anhydrous ammonia, on site
in amounts exceeding the RMP rule threshold quantities.  The listed RMP rule threshold quantity is
10,000 pounds.   Wygen 1 will store the chemical in one 12,000 gallon tank (49,400 pounds) .
The storage and management of anhydrous ammonia for this system is addressed in this RMP plan.

Anhydrous ammonia will be used at the Wygen 1 Power Plant as an air pollution control additive, to 
minimize the formation of nitrogen oxides in boiler flue gas emissions.  The boiler unit is equipped with 
selective catalytic reduction (SCR) devices.  Wygen 1 storage tank is designed at 12,000 gallons of
Anhydrous Ammonia.  This tank and associated piping system is addressed in the Risk Management
Plan.

Plant Description
The Wygen 1 Power Plant is located in Campbell County, Wyoming, at 13151 Hwy 51, Gillette, WY.
The facility is situated south of Interstate I-90 and approximately 2.5 miles east of the city of Gillette.  To
the east and also on the north side of the interstate is residential area.  Open-pit mining operations are on the west and northwest side of the plant. The property to the south of the power plant consists of reclaimed coal mine property and undeveloped grassland.  There is a recreational area called the Cam-Plex that is located to the southwest of the plant which have such events as motor-cross and horse riding occasionally; however,  the mine property is between the power plant and the Cam-Plex. This recreational and residential area were taken into consideration in the receptors section of the RMP Analysis in addition to Interstate I-90 to the north, Highway 51 to the south, and a railroad right-of-way that is located between I-90 and Wyoming Highway 51.

Ammonia System Description
The ammonia storage tank is designed to be filled by a tanker truck at a dedicated loading station.  The
tank will be maintained at a pressure of 60-200 psi, by drawing liquid ammon

ia from the bottom of the
tank, heating it in one of two electric vaporizers and routing the ammonia vapor back to the tank head
space.  For the nitrogen oxides control system, ammonia vapors will be drawn from the tanks head space,
regulated for pressure, mixed with air, and injected into the boiler flues within each respective ammonia injection grid.  In combination with the catalyst located within the selective catalyst reduction unit, nitrogen oxides will be chemically reacted with the ammonia\air mixture and emissions of the pollutant will be reduced.

The Worst Case Release Scenario
The worst case release scenario for ammonia was calculated as the loss of the storage tank in 
accordance with the definition provided in the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) guidance document 
for RMP development.  The ammonia would be released as a gas.  As allowed by the regulations, the analysis considered the administrative control systems such as the company policy to fill the tank to a maximum of 80% liquid by volume.  Additionally, the tank design will begin discharging small amounts of ammonia vapor if the tank if filled greater than 80% to warn of overfilling the tank.  The area of potential impact was determined using RMP * Comp (TM), modeling software developed b the EPA. The conditions of the scenario, such as release time and weather status are those specified in the EPA Consequence Analysis Guidance Document.  The area of potential impact was determined using the RMP*Comp, modeling software developed by the EPA.

The results of the Consequence Analysis using RMP*Comp, indicated that the ammonia would travel approximately 4,940 lbs/min under the specified weather conditions of 1.5 m/sec.  before dispersing in the atmosphere to the specified toxic endpoint concentration of 0.14mg/l with a release rate of 10.0 minutes.  Within this radius from the ammonia tanks,  seven residents with an estimated 20 people could potentially be affected.  Maps of the area and a list

of the types of receptors in the potential impact area are provided in the Off-Site Impact Analysis Section.

This type of rapid release would occur only if the ammonia tank was breached.  The likelihood of such
an incident occurring is miniscule.  Anhydrous ammonia tanks are installed with multiple safety systems
to prevent the release of an entire tank in a single event.  There have been no incidents of ammonia
tank breaches reported in the nationwide EPA - Chemical Emergency Preparedness and Prevention
Office database.

Also, in the event of a release, it is highly unlikely that the ammonia would disperse in a circular pattern
given the weather conditions in Campbell County.  During a release, it is expected that an ammonia
plume would disperse in the direction of the prevailing wind at the time of the event, as opposed to
covering the entire area defined by a circle with a radius of 1.2 miles.

Alternative Release Scenario
The alternative release scenario is, by definition, a more likely release scenario than the worst case.
Engineered controls, such as automatic shut-off valves,  check valves, relief valves, ammonia vapor
leak detection system and alarms are considered in the analysis.

The type of system failure identified for the alternative release was a loss of ammonia caused by a
a hole or puncture approx. 1.9 sq. inches inside the plant.  In the analysis the tank pressure was 200 psi. and the tank temp was 100 F.  No mitigation measures were used; although, it is likely the release could be within the plant enclosed area so the analysis may be conservative for an in-plant leak.  The calculated release rate was 302 pounds per minutes and was assumed to continue for 10 minutes or until the ammonia vapor detector sounds an alarm, alerting an operator to check the ammonia system.  The main isolation valve would be closed automatically upon alarm.  If the ammonia vapor concentration is unsafe for facility response and the main isolation doesn't clear the ammo

nia alarm, the Campbell County Fire Department will be called to respond to the emergency.  

The results of the Consequence Analysis using  RMP*Comp (TM), indicated that the ammonia would travel approximately .2  miles (1056 feet) under the specified weather conditions of temperature 77 degrees and wind speed of 3 meters/second(6.7 mph)  before dispersing to the toxic end point concentration of .14 mg\L(ppm).  Within that radius of the ammonia tank storage area, the only receptors include plant personnel and employees of the adjoining industrial facilities.  Maps of the area and a list of types of receptors in the potential impact area are provided in Off-Site Impact Analysis Section.

Process Hazard Assessment (PHA)
A process hazard assessment was performed on the ammonia system using a Reliability Centered Maintenance (RCM) technique which includes a complete environmental, safety and operation review using as a basis failure modes and effects analysis.  The ammonia tank and associated systems were reviewed for compliance with the American National Standards Institute standards for ammonia (ANSI K-61.1 - American National Standard Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia).  Compliance with  code requirements regarding the storage tank, unloading station, piping system, vaporizers, air dilution equipment and ammonia injection grid as well as operational practices and protocols with anhydrous ammonia management were assessed.  A copy of the RCM analysis is included in the Process Hazard Analysis Plan Document.

A plant assigned team of operators, maintenance planners, engineers, supervisors, and managers evaluated the system using RCM techniques.  Functional failure points in the system where the ammonia could potentially be released were identified.  Potential failure points, maintenance and inspection concerns, and standard operating procedures were reviewed for each functional failure within the system.  Comments and recommendations

are summarized in detail within the OSHA required sections of the PHA plan document.  Additionally, a corporate policy requires that each site having ammonia prepare a PHA Plan meeting the OSHA requirements.   

Prevention System
Wygen 1 Power Plant prepared operation, annunciator, and maintenance procedures for the anhydrous ammonia system.  Operating Procedures (OP), Alarm Procedures (AP)  and Maintenance Procedures (MP) have been developed based on the RCM analysis requirements, and key personnel received training before being allowed to work on the systems. The training included test certification.

The ammonia system will be visually inspected once per shift on a 24-hour per day basis.  Use of accurate  procedures, written with the participation of the PSM team will be utilized as the  primary prevention method of operating the system.  Personnel will be trained annually on safety concerns and general operation procedures as well as emergency response procedures.  Emergency response training on self-contained breathing apparatus (SCBA), worn by the operators during emergency releases of ammonia will be conducted annually and prior to system start-up. Key employees will be trained and certified annually on the safety requirements for connection/disconnection of ammonia supply components, awareness of the hazardous properties of ammonia, and the presence, location and design of ammonia detectors.

Ammonia detectors with alarms will be installed within proximity of the ammonia storage tank and ammonia injection skid and will be used to detect leaks and warn of hazards by flashing a beacon.  The storage tank will be located outdoors and the ammonia injection skid is located inside the plant. The tank will be equipped with state-of-the-art process and safety equipment.

Emergency Response Plan
The plant's Emergency Organization Plan was modified to address ammonia incident response.  Plant
personnel will be trained to respond to leaks that can be managed by shutting

off key emergency valves.
Any response requiring entry into a dangerous atmosphere or situation will be performed by the 
Campbell County Fire Department (CCFD) Haz-Mat team.  The CCFD is a member of the  Campbell County Local Emergency Planning Committee (CCLEPC).  If the situation deems necessary the CCFD will notify Campbell County Emergency Management Agency (CCEMA).  Ammonia response procedures will be discussed during an inspection by the CCFD Haz-Mat team.   A copy of the site Emergency Response Plan has been updated to include the above information.

Accident History
The Wygen 1 Power Plant is a new facility and has had no ammonia releases.
